Topic.Title: aapl offer

Message.Msg: Why would they offer $46 when Yahoo wouldn't even boost their earnings $1? They make over $40 per share so that comes out to a measly 2.5%...they could make more than that buying corporate bonds or doing a currency hedge like Yahoo did, which btw was MORE profitable last quarter than Yahoo was. Apple had revenues of $160B, last year, and buying one with $5B is pointless. Their ITunes is vastly bigger, has hundreds of TV shows, and sells something like 75% of all movies sold. Let's run some hypothetical numbers. Shares outstanding: 1.1B Yahoo Japan $9B Alibaba at 75B(10%) $7.5B...$5B after tax Alibaba final stake $150B($15B)...$10B after tax Cash and receivables: $5B if I remember right $29B/1.1=$26.36 and you want another $20 or $22B which is 4 TIMES revenue or about 25X's operating profit for a stagnant core with no moat around anything? Apple's LICENSING deal with HTC is almost as profitable as Yahoo's core and it cost them nothing. ****Apple isn't buying Yahoo as their stock buyback and debt raise boosted the share price multiple Yahoo's. Apple is in the PRODUCT business and outside of IAd they have no link together. Apples worst products have margins far higher than Yahoo even. Sounds great to dream but the reality is it would have happened long before Marissa took over if it was going to happen.

Message.Title: Alibaba Net Income More Than Doubles After Commissions Increase
Message.Msg: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., China’s largest e-commerce company, had profit that doubled in the three months ended in December after commissions may have increased. Net income at the Hangzhou, China-based Alibaba jumped to $642 million in the quarter ended December from $237 million a year earlier, according to a Yahoo! Inc. (YHOO) filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Revenue rose 80 percent to $1.8 billion, the Sunnyvale, California-based Yahoo, which owns about 24 percent stake in Alibaba, reported.

Message.Title: Yahoo up on Alibaba, Yahoo Japan results
Message.Msg: Two of Yahoo Inc. YHOO +2.38% major properties in Asia posted strong year-over-year profit growth in 2012, underscoring the value of those assets, according to a regulatory filing by Yahoo on Tuesday. Alibaba Group, in which Yahoo owns a 24% stake, saw its profit nearly triple to $642 million, according to the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Meanwhile, Yahoo Japan, in which Yahoo owns a 35% stake, posted a 13% profit gain in 2012. Alibaba's strong performance was particularly significant in the wake of speculation that the Chinese Internet giant was about to go public which is expected to result in a profit windfall for Yahoo. Yahoo jumped at the opening bell on Tuesday and was still trading up 2% to $25.68.

Message.Title: Microsoft extends Yahoo's U.S. search revenue guarantee
Message.Msg: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Microsoft Corp extended the revenue guarantee it provides to Yahoo Inc in the companies' underperforming search partnership, Yahoo said on Tuesday. The U.S. revenue-per-search guarantee, which had expired on March 31, will be extended for one year, and took effect on April 1, Yahoo said in its 10Q filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday. Yahoo also disclosed strong financial results at two of its Asian assets on Tuesday. Chinese e-commerce company Alibaba Group, in which Yahoo owns a 24 percent stake, grew revenue roughly 80 percent year-on-year to $1.84 billion in the last three months of 2012. Yahoo Japan, in which Yahoo owns a 35 percent stake, increased its net income by 13 percent to $343 million in the last three months of 2012. Shares of Yahoo were up 3.4 percent at $26.02 in mid-day trading on Tuesday.

Topic.Title: Microsoft extends Yahoo's U.S. search revenue guarantee

Message.Msg: In a note to investors on Tuesday, UBS analyst Eric Sheridan said he was raising his gross revenue estimates by $60 million over the next four quarters as a result of the extension of the guarantee.

Message.Title: Alibaba is Now Bigger Than Facebook - Great Article
Message.Msg: 20% more revenue and 10x more income per quarter!!!!! Here are the facts. In Q4, Facebook reported $1.54 billion in revenue and $64 million in net income. In Q4 (reported today, as Alibaba’s financials are reported on a 1 quarter lag in Yahoo’s filings), Alibaba did $1.84 billion and $650 million in net income. It would be odd, then, if Alibaba priced itself at $62.5 billion, given that Facebook’s market cap is currently $66 billion. Which do you think has a more sustainable long-term business model: Facebook selling ads or Alibaba transacting with 1.3 billion Chinese? If you only look at the revenue difference between the two companies, you would conclude that Alibaba should be valued at $80 billion. That suggests that Yahoo!’s 24% stake is worth $19.2 billion pre-tax or $13 billion net. Yahoo’s current market cap is $29 billion, which includes about $6.5 billion of net cash and pref shares in Alibaba, and a $6.5 billion (net) stake in Yahoo Japan. This suggests Yahoo’s “core” business is only worth about $3 billion according to the wisdom of the market (or 2x its EBITDA, when AOL AOL +2.63% (AOL) is trading at 6x). It will be fun to track just how big Facebook and Alibaba grow in the next 5 years.

Message.Title: "Who Cares About Facebook? Alibaba is Now Bigger."
Message.Msg: With all the talk over the last year about Alibaba's explosive growth, I am anxious to finally see what it IPO's at. Excerpt from Forbes: "Yet, according to the details embedded within today’s Yahoo! 10Q, Alibaba Group is now larger than Facebook. Here are the facts. In Q4, Facebook reported $1.54 billion in revenue and $64 million in net income. In Q4 (reported today, as Alibaba’s financials are reported on a 1 quarter lag in Yahoo’s filings), Alibaba did $1.84 billion and $650 million in net income. It would be odd, then, if Alibaba priced itself at $62.5 billion, given that Facebook’s market cap is currently $66 billion. Which do you think has a more sustainable long-term business model: Facebook selling ads or Alibaba transacting with 1.3 billion Chinese? If you only look at the revenue difference between the two companies, you would conclude that Alibaba should be valued at $80 billion. That suggests that Yahoo!’s 24% stake is worth $19.2 billion pre-tax or $13 billion net. Yahoo’s current market cap is $29 billion, which includes about $6.5 billion of net cash and pref shares in Alibaba, and a $6.5 billion (net) stake in Yahoo Japan. This suggests Yahoo’s “core” business is only worth about $3 billion according to the wisdom of the market (or 2x its EBITDA, when AOL AOL +2.49% (AOL) is trading at 6x).:

Message.Title: Barclays Capital raised his price target to $29 from $26
Message.Msg: Yahoo YHOO +3.58% disclosed the financial results at Alibaba and Yahoo Japan in regulatory filings on Tuesday that pointed to robust growth at both companies. The numbers at Alibaba, where Yahoo owns a 24% stake, were particularly impressive. The Chinese company saw its profit for the quarter ended Dec. 31, 2012, nearly tripling to $642 million from the year-earlier period, according to the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Meanwhile, Yahoo Japan, in which Yahoo owns a 35% stake, posted a 13% year-over-year profit gain in the same period. The disclosure sent Yahoo’s shares rising more than 3% to $26.02. Barclays Capital analyst Anthony DiClemente also raised his price target to $29 from $26 “to account for our higher Alibaba valuation, as well as a slight increase in the value of Yahoo Japan since we last marked shares to market.” Alibaba’s financials, he wrote, “show very strong continuing operating momentum for Alibaba.” Alibaba’s strong performance was particularly significant in the wake of speculation that the Chinese Internet giant was about to go public which is expected to result in a profit windfall for Yahoo.

Message.Title: Why is the RPS Guarantee not extended in Canada?
Message.Msg: "In the fourth quarter of 2011, Microsoft agreed to extend the RPS Guarantee in the U.S. and Canada through March 2013. The RPS Guarantee in the U.S. and Canada expired on March 31,2013. On April 30, 2013, Microsoft extended the RPS Guarantee in the U.S. for an additional 12 months commencing April 1, 2013. Notwithstanding any RPS Guarantee payments that we may receive, our competitors may continue to increase revenue, profitability, and market share at a higher rate than us." It was reported today that the RPS Guarantee had been extended. I read the above section in the 10Q & I am wondering why they specify throughout US/Canada & state only US has been extended. What's up with that?

Message.Title: Marissa has met with Hulu execs according to Kara Swisher...
Message.Msg: Hmmm, that would be quite a bit larger acquisition than Marissa has said Yahoo! was looking to do. I don't know, this pits Ross Levinsohn against Yahoo!/Loeb + Mayer & Levinsohn's company, Guggenheim Partners, is advising Hulu. If Yahoo! does prevail, how much more do you think they would have to pay....just sayin' Excerpt from AllThingsD: "According to numerous sources close to the situation, Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer recently met with top execs at Hulu, the premium video service whose media company owners have been considering selling it for some months. Sources said Yahoo is “in the process,” although the Silicon Valley Internet giant has not made any kind of formal bid. Other players whom sources said are considering purchasing all or parts of Hulu include: Former News Corp. COO Peter Chernin, who now has a successful and well-funded multimedia and investment company called the Chernin Group; Guggenheim Partners digital arm, which is led by former Yahoo interim CEO Ross Levinsohn; and Amazon."

Message.Msg: We're going straight to $40.....well not "straight up" per say....hehehe. After $40 we'll go to $100. Yes, say I'm crazy but you heard it from me first. There is very little overhead resistance. With the stock repurchase, continual flood of great news and PR, Alibaba, Yahoo Japan, less shares available.....you will start to see Yahoo rocket. We are just starting to see that now..... less shares available, less volume, and higher highs. It will be the classic case of supply and demand. Between hedge funds and Yahoo gobbling up shares, it's pure math. Cya guys at $40 and then straight to $100! Yes, I'm crazy......I think. But.....what if I'm correct? ; Good luck to all longs.

Topic.Title: We're going straight up to $40 :

Message.Msg: I don't think your crazy. They can reduce float to 500 million with $20 Billion in cash. At today's earnings, that's EPS of almost 4. Now add growth this year and next...Trailing P/E of 25 on 4 bucks a share. Boom. Done. $2.5 Billion in repurchases today, can add $7 billion with yahoo J sale, and another 13-15 Billion in Alibaba. Over two years of DAILY buying we can get there...

Topic.Title: Yahoo Mexico $300B+ market cap ?

Message.Msg: Actually I was a bit too harsh. So long as advertisers understand that they're pitching to "Ben Doverpal," "Hugh Janus", "Nymphetamine Doll" and tens of thousands of other colorful characters AND don't expect too much for their money, it's all good.

Message.Title: Yahoo CEO Mayer Said to Seek Ways to End Microsoft Search Deal
Message.Msg: Yahoo! Inc. Chief Executive Officer Marissa Mayer has attempted unsuccessfully to unravel a 10-year search-advertising pact with Microsoft Corp. in favor of a deal with Google Inc., according to people familiar with the matter. Mayer began the effort to end the agreement soon after becoming Yahoo CEO in July, and she has met with resistance from Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the meetings were private.

Message.Title: Alibaba Profit Nearly Triples
Message.Msg: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd.'s net profit nearly tripled in the fourth quarter, supported by an 80% rise in revenue, according to a regulatory filing by shareholder Yahoo Inc., YHOO +3.58% demonstrating a strong performance by the Chinese e-commerce giant amid expectations it is preparing for an initial public offering. Alibaba's net profit for the three months through December jumped to $642.17 million from $236.91 million a year earlier, while revenue rose to $1.84 billion from $1.02 billion, according to Yahoo's latest filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Yahoo owns a 24% stake in Alibaba.

Message.Title: Yahoo’s Mayer Has Met with Hulu Execs
Message.Msg: According to numerous sources close to the situation, Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer recently met with top execs at Hulu, the premium video service whose media company owners have been considering selling it for some months. Sources said Mayer also had an extensive getting-to-know-you meeting, which was apparently not held at Hulu’s offices in Santa Monica, Calif., along with COO Henrique De Castro.

Message.Title: Alibaba Group's fourth-quarter net profit up 171 percent
Message.Msg: China's Alibaba Group Holding Ltd posted a 171.1 percent jump in net profit in the fourth quarter as its revenue rose 84 percent, according to a regulatory filing by major shareholder Yahoo Inc. For the quarter ending December 2012, net income attributable to Alibaba Group was $642.2 million while its revenue for the period was $1.84 billion, the filing said. Yahoo, which owns about 24 percent of Alibaba, reported the privately held online shopping giant's results as part of a document filed to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

Topic.Title: Yahoo CEO Mayer Said to Seek Ways to End Microsoft Search Deal

Message.Msg: Yahoo allowed their search results to be "powered by google" in the first place years ago. Guess what happened? Tons of Yahoo users started going straight to Google. The rest is history. I find it laughable Yahoo now wants to team up with Google again in search. If I were Yahoo, I would immediately fire anyone (regardless of their position) with such thoughts of repeating the past. This is truly hysterical.

Topic.Title: wow really, i jumped ship at 24.80

Message.Msg: Why would you sell after looking at the financials and the money making machine alibaba is. Compare yahoo to its peers and it is grossly undervalued!

Topic.Title: Yahoo CEO Mayer Said to Seek Ways to End Microsoft Search Deal

Message.Msg: the next content search will be landed in video field. Microsoft had better start right now or will find itself behind the next wave again. We are talking about Ad dollars here and who can dominate this field if not labeling every search result as powered by Youtube. A platform is the key. YouTube has it and to be refined with more clear definitions of social groups/segments. An end user can hardly master segmentation of social interests where Google can apply more precise marketing technique associated with exiting search engine. Let's assume Google has enough statisticians working on end user profiles and categorize them into commercially useful segment. Where does FB fit into all these?
